post: Taking a trip to Rome, and have some questions

comment.body: we went last summer (never again, hot and nuts - it's good you're going when you are). we relied on [viator.com](https://www.viator.com/Rome/d511-ttd?pid=P00112302&mcid=42383&medium=link&medium_version=selector&campaign=reddit-rome-all-hl) for literally all of what you're after. they have skip the line tours, bus tours to tivoli, etc. it's great because they deal with the tickets. it's also a good place to start to see what travelers are saying (reviews), operators, pricing, timing, etc. for the flea market, i believe you're talking about the porta portese just south of trastevere. it is worth it (imho). hope this helps!

1. Yes, it's 30 days before to the minute (and no, this information is not in our Wiki, although I do recommend to check that page out neverthelessy)

2. In a regular year, we collectively suggest not to bother booking Pantheon tickets ahead of time because lines move pretty fast. However, the Jubilee is upon us, so there is no telling how crowded the city will be by the time you come. The amount of pilgrims coming to the city on top of the regular tourist flows are a great unknown, so if you can access the museiitaliani website with no issue (many tourists from abroad have had a hard time paying for their tickets on that platform), go ahead and try and snatch those tickets as soon as it is possible. 

3. It's not uncommon for the Scavi office to reply only a few weeks or even DAYS before the date of your visit, so it's not uncommon for you not to have heard back from them. As for the second part of your question, you cannot buy tickets in advance for the dome.

4. You can access the Mamertine Prison with an Omnia Card (Vatican-issued city pass; this is because that site specifically is maintained by the Vatican). Not sure whether you can buy a ticket at the door.

5. If you're not familiar with the public transportation network here, it could be hard-er to get to Tivoli. Not Villa d'Este - that one is straightforward on account of only needing a train ride. However, Hadrian's Villa can be overwhelming to a newbie to the Cotral bus  system, which takes you closer to the site. Because of that alone, save yourself from the hassle and get thee a tour.

6. Your partner heard about Porta Portese. As a long time visitor to that, my suggestion is don't bother going unless a) your expectations are really low; b) you accept that you'll have to wake up extremely early to find the best bargains; and c) you'll limit your visit to the Via Angelo Bargoni/Via Ippolito Nievo area. And even that is seriously crammed with junk.

Luckily enough there are plenty of other flea markets (mostly indoors) that you can visit and they are for the most part open every day of the week. Check out mercatinousato.com for a popular chain with dozens of branches.

I'm going to Rome in the first week of February so can't contribute too much except that I got my scavi tickets 3 weeks ago for the 3rd of feb, after applying in late August. Given your trip is around 3 weeks after mine I wouldn't give up hope completely just yet.
